entry.title: Response to comments on ``Theoretical mathematics''
entry.summary: The authors discuss various objections and rejoinders in the collected responses [math.HO/9404229,math.HO/9404236] to their original article on the relationship between mathematics and theoretical physics [math.HO/9307227].

entry.title: Editor's column (on an article by Jaffe and Quinn)
entry.summary: This note is a preface to various responses [math.HO/9404229,math.HO/9404236] to an opinion piece by Jaffe and Quinn [math.HO/9307227] on the relationship between mathematics and theoretical physics.

entry.title: Asymptotic behaviour of Turing Machines
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn. See published paper http://arxiv.org/math.HO/0512390
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn. See published paper http://arxiv.org/math.HO/0512390

entry.title: Some personal reminiscences of Olga Taussky
entry.summary: The title says it all

entry.title: On the section of a cone
entry.summary: A problem from Democritus is used to illustrate the building, and use, of infinitesimal covectors from its regularized, finite, counterpart.

entry.title: The Modular Tree of Pythagorus
entry.summary: The Pythagorean triples have the structure of a ternary rooted tree; the tree is based on the Cayley graph of a free subgroup of the modular group

entry.title: Short Calculus
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author

entry.title: Notes on Linear Algebra
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author

entry.title: The Life and Works of Raoul Bott
entry.summary: a 10-page biography of Raoul Bott followed by a 25-page discussion of his major papers

entry.title: Weierstra√ü
entry.summary: We give a short biographical sketch of Karl Weierstrass.
entry.arxiv:comment: 5 pages; intended for high school students and teachers

entry.title: Noether
entry.summary: We give a short biographical sketch of Emmy Noether.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages; intended for high school students

entry.title: Flashes of noncommutativity
entry.summary: Noncommutativity lays hidden in the proofs of classical dynamics. Modern frameworks can be used to bring it to light: *-products, groupoids, q-deformed calculus, etc.

entry.title: Saunders Mac Lane, the Knight of Mathematics
entry.summary: This is a short obituary of Saunders Mac Lane (1909--2005).

entry.title: Traits
entry.summary: Reminiscences about Alexandr Danilovich Alexandrov (1912--1999)
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Siberian Electronic Mathematical Reports, Vol. 9, A44--A61 (2012)

entry.title: The prime analog of the Kepler-Bouwkamp constant
entry.summary: The prime analog of the Kepler-Bouwkamp constant is evaluated.

entry.title: The regularized product of the Fibonacci numbers
entry.summary: The regularized product of the Fibonacci numbers is evaluated.

entry.title: Excursus into the History of Calculus
entry.summary: This is a brief overview of some turning points in the history of infinitesimals.

entry.title: Alexandrov Par Excellence
entry.summary: This is a short tribute to Alexandr Alexandrov (1912--1999).

entry.title: Why prove things?
entry.summary: We illustrate the concept of mathematical proof.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages, 4 figures; intended for high school students

entry.title: On Categorical Theory-Building: Beyond the Formal
entry.summary: I propose a notion of theory motivated by Category theory.

entry.title: Origami constructions
entry.summary: A characterization of real numbers constructible by paper folding.

entry.title: A Note on Walk versus Wait: Lazy Mathematician Wins
entry.summary: Points out the errors in the paper "J.G. Chen, S.D. Kominers, and R.W. Sinnott. Walk versus wait: The lazy mathematician wins. arXiv.org Mathematics 2008. arXiv:0801.0297"

entry.title: New Proof of the Equation $\sum_{k=1}^\infty \frac{Œº(k)}{k}=0.$
entry.summary: This is an English translation of Edmund Landau's Doctoral Dissertation.

entry.title: Proving Touchard's Theorem From Euler's Form
entry.summary: This paper derives Touchard's theorem from Euler's form for odd perfect numbers. It also fine-tunes Euler's form.

entry.title: The Laguerre polynomials preserve real-rootedness
entry.summary: The linear transformation that sends $x^n$ to the n'th Laguerre polynomial preserves real-rootedness.

entry.title: Le logo du CNRS est-il convexe ?
entry.summary: In october 2008, CNRS adopts a new logo with a round shape. We study the mathematical representation of this shape, and in particular its convexity.

entry.title: Alexey Vasilyevich Pogorelov, the mathematician of an incredible power
entry.summary: Life and the mathematical legacy of the great mathematician A.V. Pogorelov.

entry.title: A discrete Faa di Bruno's formula
entry.summary: We derive some formulas that rule the behaviour of finite differences under composition of functions with vector values and arguments.

entry.title: Poincar√© et les quanta
entry.summary: We present some reflections concerning two papers by H. Poincar\'e concerning the theory of quanta.

entry.title: Minimal counting systems and commutative monoids
entry.summary: These notes present an approach to obtaining the basic operations of addition and multiplication on the natural numbers in terms of elementary results about commutative monoids.

entry.title: A first course in Local arithmetic
entry.summary: Notes for a course at the H.-C. R. I., Allahabad, 15 August 2008 -- 26 January 2009

entry.title: Bidding chess
entry.summary: An expository introduction to bidding chess and other bidding games. To appear in Mathematical Intelligencer.

entry.title: The ultimate question
entry.summary: We present a planar hypohamiltonian graph on 42 vertices and show some consequences.

entry.title: Desperately seeking mathematical proof
entry.summary: Remarks on mathematical proof and the practice of mathematics.

entry.title: Algorithmic Information Theory and Foundations of Probability
entry.summary: The use of algorithmic information theory (Kolmogorov complexity theory) to explain the relation between mathematical probability theory and `real world' is discussed.

entry.title: A young person's guide to the Hopf fibration
entry.summary: These notes were used for a two week summer course on the Hopf fibration taught to high school students.

entry.title: Newton Revisited: An excursion in Euclidean geometry
entry.summary: An interpretation of selected parts of Newton's Principia, with modern notation and methods. Keplers Laws are derived from an inverse square law using Newton's methods.

entry.title: Classical Philology. Notes on Fermat's way of thinking
entry.summary: This study use some philological and historical means in order to understand Fermat's way of thinking.

entry.title: The Full Pythagorean Theorem
entry.summary: We motivate and then prove a generalized pythagorean theorem for parallelepipeds in Euclidean space.

entry.title: A new limit representation of pi
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn
entry.arxiv:comment: Due to the non-originality of the result

entry.title: Sur les origines du cocycle de Virasoro
entry.summary: This article gives a short sketch of the origins of Virasoro cocycle, both in algebra and quantum field theory.

entry.title: Vladimir Igorevich Arnold
entry.summary: In the following article a Ph.D. student of V.I.~Arnold gives a personal account on his teacher who unexpectedly passed away earlier this year.

entry.title: Invariants of polynomials and binary forms
entry.summary: We survey various classical results on invariants of polynomials, or equivalently, of binary forms, focussing on explicit calculations for invariants of polynomials of degrees 2, 3, 4.

entry.title: Some beautiful q-analogues of Fibonacci and Lucas polynomials
entry.summary: We give an overview about well-known basic properties of two classes of q-Fibonacci and q-Lucas polynomials and offer a common generalization.

entry.title: Zum 200. Geburtstag von Evariste Galois
entry.summary: We throw a brief glance at Galois' life, on the occasion of his 200th anniversary (written in German).

entry.title: A simple proof of Jordan normal form
entry.summary: In this note, a simple proof Jordan normal form and rational form of matrices over a field is given.

entry.title: A Criticism on "A Mathematician's Apology" by G. H. Hardy
entry.summary: This paper is a criticism on "A Mathematician's Apology" by G. H. Hardy.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Gazette des Mathematiciens, France, vol 100, p. 83-86 (2004)

entry.title: Tricky Arithmetic
entry.summary: This article is an expanded version of my talk at the Gathering for Gardner, 2012.

entry.title: Utilization of technology for mathematical talks. An alarming situation
entry.summary: We discuss the process of deterioration of quality of mathematical conferences caused by computer presentations.

entry.title: An Etruscan Dodecahedron
entry.summary: The paper is proposing a short discussion on the ancient knowledge of Platonic solids, in particular, by Italic people.

entry.title: Some history about Twin Prime Conjecture
entry.summary: This article is a collected information from some books and papers, and in most cases the original sentences is reserved about twin prime conjecture.

entry.title: Trigonometry of The Gold-Bug
entry.summary: The classic Edgar Allan Poe story The Gold-Bug involves digging for pirate treasure. Locating the digging sites requires some simple trigonometry.

entry.title: Continued fraction expansion for function sec(x) + tan(x)
entry.summary: The autor propose the elementary derivation of the continued fraction expansion for function sec(x) + tan(x).

entry.title: Conway's Wizards
entry.summary: I present and discuss a puzzle about wizards invented by John H. Conway.

entry.title: A proof of the Quadratic Reciprocity Law
entry.summary: A proof of the Quadratic Reciprocity Law is presented using a Lemma of Gauss, the theory of finite fields and the Frobenius automorfism.

entry.title: Todas as afirma√ß√µes verdadeiras s√£o demonstr√°veis
entry.summary: In this instructional exposition in Portuguese for the popularisation of mathematics, we state and prove the completeness theorem.

entry.title: Mathematics Hidden Behind the Two Coefficients of Babylonian Mathematics
entry.summary: In the present paper I shall reveal two circular figures hidden behind the Susa mathematical text no.3,lines 5 and 6 with my own analysis of the text.

entry.title: Schr√∂der e la Teoria dei Gruppi
entry.summary: This short paper focuses on Schr\"oder's contribute towards a structural view of group theory.

entry.title: Translation of the C.J. Malmst√©n's paper De integralibus quibusdam definitis, seriebusque infinitis
entry.summary: We translate the paper De Integralibus quibusdam definitis, seriebusque infinitis
entry.arxiv:comment: 47 pages, just a translation with a little introduction and additional notes

entry.title: Parallel Weighings
entry.summary: I introduce, solve and generalize a new coin puzzle that involves parallel weighings.

entry.title: How to Construct a Large Table of Babylonian Mathematics
entry.summary: In the present paper I shall clarify the Babylonian method by which many large tables of reciprocals could be constructed.

entry.title: Tibetan calendar mathematics
entry.summary: The calculations of the Tibetan calendar are described, using modern mathematical notations instead of the traditional methods.

entry.title: The Hockey Stick Theorems in Pascal and Trinomial Triangles
entry.summary: We have found some patterns in some triangles.

entry.title: Routh's Theorem for Tetrahedra
entry.summary: We give a geometric proof of the Routh's theorem for tetrahedra.

entry.title: Classical Reciprocity Laws
entry.summary: Using the quadratic reciprocity law as the motivating example, we convey an understanding of classical reciprocity laws.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Asia Pacific Mathematics Newsletter, October 2014, Vol 4, No 4, pp. 5--9

entry.title: Attacking ApSimon's Mints
entry.summary: ApSimon's Mints problem is a very difficult and often misunderstood counterfeit-coin puzzle. I explain the problem and suggest ways to approach it, while giving several fun exercises for the reader.

entry.title: √Ålbum de figurinhas da Copa do Mundo: uma abordagem via cadeias de Markov
entry.summary: Using Markov chains, we present some probabilistic comments about the sticker album of 2014 Fifa World Cup.

entry.title: Book Review: Matrix Theory by X. Zhan
entry.summary: This is a book review for Zhan's Matrix Theory (AMS, GSM 147, 2013).

entry.title: Math-Selfie
entry.summary: This is a write up on some sections of convex geometry, functional analysis, optimization, and nonstandard models that attract the author.

entry.title: Memoria of Valery Anatolievich Senderov
entry.summary: The paper dedicated to memory of Valery Anatolievich Senderov

entry.title: Karl Weierstrass Bicentenary
entry.summary: Academic biography of Karl Weierstrass, his basic works, influence of his doctrine on the development of mathematics.

entry.title: Demystifying Benjamin Franklin's other 8-square
entry.summary: In this article, we reveal how Benjamin Franklin constructed his second $8 \times 8$ magic square. We also construct two new $8 \times 8$ Franklin squares.

entry.title: Flat origami and constructions
entry.summary: We discuss well known geometric constructions via paper-folding. The note is written primary for school students.
entry.arxiv:comment: Old paper with corrections. in Russian

entry.title: Expected n-Step Product for Gaussian Tours
entry.summary: Supplements to Mehta & Normand (1997) are given, with regard to integrals involving Euclidean distances between n+1 random points in d-dimensional space, each visited once.

entry.title: Challenges to Some Philosophical Claims about Mathematics
entry.summary: In this note some philosophical thoughts and observations about mathematics are expressed, arranged as challenges to some common claims.

entry.title: Nice Neighbors: A brief adventure in mathematical gamification
entry.summary: This is an expository article about the topological theory of digital images, and a gamification of a research project.

entry.title: Un problema da discutere: un inganno con le percentuali
entry.summary: We discuss a non-intuitive situation concerning percentages.

entry.title: Gli angoli alla base di un triangolo isoscele
entry.summary: This paper deals with the celebrated Euclidean theorem about isosceles triangles, comparing different proofs.

entry.title: Un problema da discutere: una rappresentazione geometrica del teorema del coseno
entry.summary: We present, discuss and generalize an elegant geometrical proof of the law of cosines, due to Al Cuoco.

entry.title: B√ºrgi's "Kunstweg" - geometric approach
entry.summary: Placing regular 4n-sided polygons correctly, equations between sine and sums of sines show up -- exactly these equations are used in B\"urgi's method to approximate sines.

entry.title: Transcriptions of Six Letters of Bernhard Riemann Preserved in the SIL
entry.summary: The German transcriptions of six letters of Bernhard Riemann preserved in the Smithsonian Libraries (SIL) in Washington DC are given.

entry.title: Dragons and Kasha
entry.summary: Kasha-eating dragons introduce advanced mathematics. The goal of this paper is twofold: to entertain people who know advanced mathematics and inspire people who don't.

entry.title: On the motion of a viscous liquid filling space
entry.summary: A translation to English of the 1934 paper of Leray, Sur le mouvement d'un liquide visqueux emplissant l'espace.

entry.title: On existence of a triangle with prescribed bisector lengths
entry.summary: We suggest a geometric visualization of the process of constructing a triangle with prescribed bisectors that makes the existence of such a triangle geometrically evident.

entry.title: Pythagoras' theorem via equilateral triangles
entry.summary: We give a proof of Pythagoras' theorem which does not use neither squares nor similarity of triangles.

entry.title: Una tentazione affascinante
entry.summary: We discuss several aspects of infinity in the history of mathematics.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Asimmetrie, Rivista dell'Istituto Nazionale di Fisica Nucleare, 2016

entry.title: Tessellations
entry.summary: A survey of tessellations, which appeared in Italian in La Matematica vol 3 in 2010. The Tiling Lemma appears for the first time.

entry.title: A Special Theorem Related to the Fagnano's Problem
entry.summary: A special theorem related to the Fagnano's problem is proved and an example of the theorem is shown in a golden rectangle.

entry.title: A Conic Section Problem Involving the Maximum Generalized Golden Right Triangle
entry.summary: An interesting conic section problem involving the maximum generalized golden right triangle $T_2$ is solved, and two simple constructions of $T_2$ are shown.

entry.title: Fermat's Last Theorem: Algebra, Geometry, and Number Theory
entry.summary: In our work we give the examples using Fermat's Last Theorem for solving some problems from algebra, geometry and number theory

entry.title: Guess the Larger Number
entry.summary: We discuss variations of the zero-sum game where Bob selects two distinct numbers, and Alice learns one of them to make a guess which of the numbers is the larger.

entry.title: Yuri Safarov (1958-2015)
entry.summary: This is the editor's preface to the special issue of Journal of Spectral Theory, in memory of Yuri Safarov.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Journal of Spectral Theory, 2016, vol. 6, p. 685-694

entry.title: A translation of "Verallgemeinerung des Sylow'schen Satzes" by F. G. Frobenius
entry.summary: A translation of "Verallgemeinerung des Sylow'schen Satzes" by F. G. Frobenius, Sitzungsberichte K. Preuss. Akad. Wiss. Berlin, 1895 (II).

entry.title: A simple proof of Feuerbach's theorem
entry.summary: The theorem of Feuerbach states that the nine-point circle of a nonequilateral triangle is tangent to both its incircle and its three excircles. We give a simple proof of this theorem.

entry.title: A proof of the butterfly theorem using the scale factor between the two wings
entry.summary: We give a new proof of the butterfly theorem, based on the use of several expressions involving the scale factor between the two wings.

entry.title: Richard Dedekind: Brief an Keferstein / Letter to Keferstein
entry.summary: This is an edition of the famous letter by Richard Dedekind to H. Keferstein dated 27 February 1890

entry.title: On self-affine sets
entry.summary: We survey the dimension theory of self-affine sets for general mathematical audience. The article is in Finnish.

entry.title: An alternative quadratic formula
entry.summary: The classical quadratic formula and some of its lesser known variants for solving the quadratic equation are reviewed. Then, a new formula for the roots of a quadratic polynomial is presented.

entry.title: Obituary: Walter Benz (1931-2017)
entry.summary: Emeritus Professor Dr. Dr. h.c. Walter Benz passed away on 13 January 2017.

entry.title: Efficiently constructing tangent circles
entry.summary: Our goal is to present, in what we believe is the most efficient way possible, a construction of four mutually tangent circles.

entry.title: PVC Polyhedra
entry.summary: We describe how to construct a dodecahedron, tetrahedron, cube, and octahedron out of pvc pipes using standard fittings.

entry.title: Explanation of a Polynomial Identity
entry.summary: In this note, we provide a conceptual explanation of a well-known polynomial identity used in algebraic number theory.

entry.title: Historia matheseos. Early development stage history of mathematics, historiography
entry.summary: This article focuses on evolvement of the history of mathematics as a science and development of its methodology from the 4th century B.C. to the age of Enlightenment.

entry.title: Assessments in Mathematics, undergraduate degree
entry.summary: In the sequel, we question the validity of multiple choice questionnaires for undergraduate level math courses. Our study is based on courses given in major French universities, to numerous audiences.

entry.title: Scalar curvature, flat Borromean rings, and the 3-body problem
entry.summary: This paper explains unexpected links between the 3 topics in the title and frames them in a large canvas.

entry.title: On proof and progress in mathematics
entry.summary: In response to Jaffe and Quinn [math.HO/9307227], the author discusses forms of progress in mathematics that are not captured by formal proofs of theorems, especially in his own work in the theory of foliations and geometrization of 3-manifolds and dynamical systems.

entry.title: Differential interactive games: The short-term predictions
entry.summary: Procedures of the short-term predictions for processes in general 2-person differential interactive games are proposed. Their effectiveness is discussed.

entry.title: Representative dynamics
entry.summary: This short note is devoted to the representative dynamics, which realizes a link between the theory of controlled systems and representation theory. Dynamical inverse problem of representation theory for controlled systems is considered: to solve it means to correspond a representative dynamics to the controlled system.

entry.title: A Quartic Surface of Integer Hexahedra
entry.summary: Using a quartic surface and its rational curves we can give an infinite number of integer hexahedra; these are 6 sided 3d solids, each face a trapezoid, with all sides and diagonals having intger lengths.

entry.title: Life and work of the mathemagician Srinivasa Ramanujan
entry.summary: The Life of Srinivasa Ramanujan (1887 - 1920), the renowned Indian Mathematician, is presented, in this the first of a series of lectures, delivered at the Indian Institute for Advanced Study, Shimla.

author.name: K. Srinivasa Rao
author.arxiv:affiliation: The Institute of Mathematical Sciences, Chennai, India

entry.title: q-Newton binomial: from Euler to Gauss
entry.summary: A counter-intuitive result of Gauss (formulae (1.6), (1.7) below) is made less mysterious by virtue of being generalized through the introduction of an additional parameter.

entry.title: The Legacy of the IST
entry.summary: We provide a brief review of some of the major research results arising from the method of the Inverse Scattering Transform.

entry.title: Why I don't like "pure mathematics"
entry.summary: An opiniated essay on what pure mathematics is and why the adjective "pure" in "pure mathematics" is not a good choice.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages; written for high school students and teachers

entry.title: Solving the quartic with a pencil
entry.summary: This expository paper presents the general solution of a quartic equation as a jump off point to introduce Lefschetz fibrations. It should be accessible to a broad audience.

entry.title: Classical Lebesgue Integration Theorems for the Riemann Integral
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn due to an error, and no further revisions will be made.

entry.title: Biography of John Rainwater
entry.summary: The following paragraphs will describe the origins of John Rainwater, the impact of his work, the motivations for various parts of it and the prospects for his future.

entry.title: Summary of Delsarte's "Nombre de Solutions des Equations Polynomiales sur un Corps Fini"
entry.summary: An English summary is given of Jean Delsarte's article "Nombre de solutions des equations polynomiales sur un corps fini."

entry.title: Role of Mathematics in Physical Sciences
entry.summary: The role of mathematics in physical sciences is discussed, particularly how higher mathematics found applications in empirical problems. Several examples are given to illustrate this role.
entry.arxiv:comment: no figure, 11 pages, Based on the talk given at the first national seminar on mathematics organized by Pakistan Mathematical Society, January 2004

entry.title: Leibniz, Randomness and the Halting Probability
entry.summary: This paper, which is dedicated to Alan Turing on the 50th anniversary of his death, gives an overview and discusses the philosophical implications of incompleteness, uncomputability and randomness.

entry.title: Trisections and Totally Real Origami
entry.summary: We introduce a trisection axiom for mathematical origami and descibe the totally real origami numbers. We also discuss the solution of Alhazen's problem and its relation to trisections.

entry.title: Maxwell's daemon, the Turing machine, and Jaynes' robot
entry.summary: A review of Jaynes' posthumous book "Probability Theory--The Logic of Science." I use scientific and personality elements gathered from other papers by Jaynes to help throw light on the origins of Jaynes' life quest.

entry.title: Irreducible Complexity in Pure Mathematics
entry.summary: By using ideas on complexity and randomness originally suggested by the mathematician-philosopher Gottfried Leibniz in 1686, the modern theory of algorithmic information is able to show that there can never be a "theory of everything" for all of mathematics.

entry.title: How real are real numbers?
entry.summary: We discuss mathematical and physical arguments against continuity and in favor of discreteness, with particular emphasis on the ideas of Emile Borel (1871-1956).

entry.title: Strange Integrals Derived By Elementary Complex Analysis
entry.summary: In this short note, we provide an elementary complex analytic method for converting known real integrals into numerous strange and interesting looking real integrals.

entry.title: Course of differential geometry
entry.summary: This book is a textbook for the basic course of differential geometry. It is recommended as an introductory material for this subject.
entry.arxiv:comment: The textbook, AmSTeX, 132 pages, amsppt style, prepared for double side printing on letter size paper

entry.title: Christiaan Huygens and contact geometry
entry.summary: This article is based on the author's inaugural lecture at the University of Cologne on 24 January 2003.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in Nieuw Archief voor Wiskunde

entry.title: Looking through newly to the amazing irrationals
entry.summary: We survay some nice result concerning the irrationals with a metric space point of view.Here is ofcourse nothing new may be or an expert in this field.
entry.arxiv:comment: 15 pages, Here irrationals are reviewd from a metric space point

entry.title: Integer Triangles with R/r=N
entry.summary: We consider the problem of finding integer-sided triangles with R/r an integer, where R and r are the radii of the circumcircle and incircle respectively. We show that such triangles are relatively rare.

entry.title: The functional equation of the zeta function of a global field
entry.summary: We write down the functional equation of the zeta function of a global field. This equation is implicit in Weil's ``Basic Number Theory''.

entry.title: The Tao of Mathematics, and Think Locally
entry.summary: An informal discussion of Serre's conjecture on the modularity of odd irreducible representations of Gal(\bar Q|Q) into GL_2(\bar F_p), using Ramanujan's tau-function as an illustrative example. Also, a word about the importance of thinking locally.
entry.arxiv:comment: Text of two talks at Bangalore, August 2005

entry.title: Numbers and periods
entry.summary: A somewhat pretentious presentation of number systems (N, Z, Q, R, C, Q_p, >...). The problem of a p-adic characterisation of good-reduction p-adic curves is posed.
entry.arxiv:comment: Notes from a talk at Allahabad, February 2006

entry.title: Uncountable sets and an infinite real number game
entry.summary: We give a short proof of the well-known fact that the unit interval [0,1] is uncountable by means of a simple infinite game. We also show using this game that a (non-empty) perfect subset of [0,1] must be uncountable.

entry.title: Aryabhata's Root Extraction Methods
entry.summary: We investigate the mathematics behind 1500 year old root extraction methods presented by Aryabhata in his famous mathematical treatise "Aryabhatiya". Also, we look at their computational complexity.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Indian Journal of History of Science, 42.2 (2007) 149-161

entry.title: A note on the Artin Conjecture
entry.summary: In this paper, we survey some recent results on the Artin conjecture and discuss some aspects for the Artin conjecture.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Trends in Mathematics, Vol. 9, No. 1, June 2006, pp. 99-107

entry.title: On the Church-Turing thesis
entry.summary: This paper has been withdrawn by the author
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author

entry.title: The Halting Probability Omega: Irreducible Complexity in Pure Mathematics
entry.summary: Some Goedel centenary reflections on whether incompleteness is really serious, and whether mathematics should be done somewhat differently, based on using algorithmic complexity measured in bits of information. [Enriques lecture given Monday, October 30, 2006, at the University of Milan.]

entry.title: Representations of finite groups
entry.summary: This book is an introduction to a fast developing branch of mathematics - the theory of representations of groups. It presents classical results of this theory concerning finite groups.

entry.title: Linear Programming and Kantorovich Spaces
entry.summary: This is a brief overview of the life of Leonid Kantorovich (1912--1986) and his contribution to the fields of linear programming and ordered vector spaces.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: J. Appl. Indust. Math., 2007, V.1, No.2, 137-141

entry.title: A simple reformulation of Riemann Zeta function
entry.summary: We rewrite Riemann Zeta function as a sum over the primes. Each term of the sum is a product that depends only on the summation index (a prime) and the primes following it.

entry.title: Algorithmic information theory: Some recollections
entry.summary: Presents a history of the evolution of the author's ideas on program-size complexity and its applications to metamathematics over the course of more than four decades. Includes suggestions for further work.

entry.title: What is good mathematics?
entry.summary: Some personal thoughts and opinions on what ``good quality mathematics'' is, and whether one should try to define this term rigorously. As a case study, the story of Szemer\'edi's theorem is presented.
entry.arxiv:comment: 12 pages, no figures. To appear, Bull. Amer. Math. Soc

entry.title: Mathematical knowledge: internal, social and cultural aspects
entry.summary: I discuss some general aspects of the creation, interpretation, and reception of mathematics as a part of civilization and culture.
entry.arxiv:comment: Commissioned for vol. 2 of ``Mathematics and Culture'', ed. by C. Bartocci and P. Odifreddi

entry.title: Probabilita` e Paradosso (Probability and Paradox)
entry.summary: In this paper we present three simple applications of probability and highlight and discuss their paradoxical flavour.
entry.arxiv:comment: Plain LaTeX, 9 pages, one figure. Text in Italian
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Il Giornale di Fisica, VOL. XLV, N.4, Ott.-Dic. 2004

entry.title: A general method for investigating the roots of all equations by approximation
entry.summary: Translation of the Latin original, "Methodus generalis investigandi radices omnium aequationum per approximationem" (1776). E643 in the Enestrom index. Euler gives a series to find powers of roots of polynomials.

entry.title: Order from Randomness
entry.summary: We consider an elementary discrete process which starts from purely random configuration and leads to well-ordered and stable state. Complete analytical solution to this problem is presented.

entry.title: Publication history of von Staudt's Geometrie der Lage
entry.summary: From a census of forty copies, we can distinguish three different editions of von Staudt's Geometrie der Lage: the first of 1847 and two undated ones from the 1870's.

entry.title: Complex cobordism and algebraic topology
entry.summary: This is a historical survey, beginning where Atiyah and Sullivan leave off...
entry.arxiv:comment: This is an attempt to supplement recent [BAMS 2004] accounts of Ren\'e Thom's work on cobordism theory with a description of that subject's later evolution -- in particular, its connection with the local Langlands program

entry.title: Cesaro's integral formula for the Bell numbers (corrected)
entry.summary: M. E. Cesaro (1885) gave a quite remarkable expression for the Bell number --the number of partitions of an n-element set -- as a definite integral. This note is an exposition, correcting a typographical error in the original.

entry.title: Sobolev Institute of Mathematics Celebrates its Fiftieth Anniversary
entry.summary: This paper describes briefly history and current state of the Sobolev Institute of Mathematics, the biggest research mathematical institute of the Russian Academy of Sciences located east to Ural mountains.

entry.title: Counterexamples in Cake-Cutting
entry.summary: This article contains counterexamples to theorems and claims in Brams, Jones and Klamler's article "Better Ways to Cut a Cake" in the December 2006 Notices of the American Mathematical Society.

entry.title: Through a Glass Darkly
entry.summary: We consider the question of how mathematicians view themselves and how non-mathematicians view us. What is our role in society? Is it effective? Is it rewarding? How could it be improved? This paper will be part of a forthcoming volume on this circle of questions.

entry.title: Desperately seeking mathematical truth
entry.summary: This article discusses epistemological problems in the philosophy of mathematics and issues concerning the reliability of the mathematical literature.
entry.arxiv:comment: This article has been published on the Opinion page of the Notices of the American Mathematical Society, August, 2008

entry.title: Constructing the Primitive Roots of Prime Powers
entry.summary: We use only addition and multiplication to construct the primitive roots of $p^{k+1}$ from the primitive roots of $p^{k}$, where $p$ is an odd prime and $k$ is at least 2.

entry.title: In whose mind is Mathematics an "a priori cognition"?
entry.summary: According to the philosopher Kant, Mathematics is an "a priori cognition". Kant's assumption, together with the unsolvability of Hilbert's 10th problem, implies an astonishing result.

entry.title: David George Kendall, a biographical account
entry.summary: This biographical account of the life and work of David Kendall includes details of his personal and professional activities. Kendall is probably best known for his work in applied probability, especially queueing theory, and in stochastic analysis and spatial statistics.
entry.arxiv:comment: Higher definition figures available via author's website

entry.title: Masaki Kashiwara and Algebraic Analysis
entry.summary: This paper is a brief overview of the main contributions of Masaki Kashiwara in the domain of microlocal and algebraic analysis.
entry.arxiv:comment: 9 pages, 4 figures. Talk given in honor of Masaki Kashiwara's 60th birthday, Kyoto, June 27, 2007. To appear in Advances in Pure Mathematics (2009)

entry.title: Some additive relations in the Pascal triangle
entry.summary: We derive some, seemingly new, curious additive relations in the Pascal triangle. They arise in summing up the numbers in the triangle along some vertical line up to some place.

entry.title: An Unusual Proof that the Reals are Uncountable
entry.summary: This somewhat unusual proof for the fact that the reals are uncountable, which is adapted from one of Bourbaki's proofs in "Fonctions d'une variable reelle", may be of some interest.
entry.arxiv:comment: One page. Adapted from one of Bourbaki's proofs in "Fonctions d'une variable reelle"

entry.title: Book Review: "Geometry of Quantum States" by Ingemar Bengtsson and Karol Zyczkowski (Cambridge University Press, 2006)
entry.summary: Invited book review, as submitted to the electronic database MathSciNet, of the 2006 Cambridge University Press book, "Geometry of Quantum States," by Ingemar Bengtsson and Karol Zyczkowski

entry.title: Optimal profiles in variable speed flows
entry.summary: Where a 2D problem of optimal profile in variable speed flow is resolved in a class of convex Bezier curves, using symbolic and numerical computations.

entry.title: Representation of One as the Sum of Unit Fractions
entry.summary: One is expressed as the sum of the reciprocals of a certain set of integers. We give an elegant proof to the fact applying the polynomial theorem and basic calculus.

entry.title: Irrationality From The Book
entry.summary: We generalize Tennenbaum's geometric proof of the irrationality of sqrt(2) to sqrt(n) for n = 3, 5, 6 and 10.

entry.title: Gold ratio and a trigonometric identity
Aronszajn's Criterion for Euclidean Space
entry.summary: We give a simple proof of a characterization of euclidean space due to Aronszajn and derive a well-known characterization due to Jordan & von Neumann as a corollary.

entry.title: On the construction of a triangle from the feet of its angle bisectors
entry.summary: We study the problem of construction of a triangle from the feet of its internal angle bisectors. It is proved that in general case ruler-and-compass solution of this problem is impossible.

entry.title: Real numbers as infinite decimals and irrationality of $\sqrt{2}$
entry.summary: In order to prove irrationality of \sqrt{2} by using only decimal expansions (and not fractions), we develop in detail a model of real numbers based on infinite decimals and arithmetic operations with them.

entry.title: Polya by Examples
entry.summary: Polya Enumeration Theorem is one of the most useful tools dealing with the enumeration of patterns that are symmetric in some ways. What follows is a procedure for obtaining the results of Polya Theorem directly, bypassing the usual preliminaries.

entry.title: The Lemniscate of Bernoulli, Without Formulas
entry.summary: In this paper we give purely geometrical proofs of the well-known properties of the lemniscate of Bernoulli.

entry.title: Linear Representation of Lie Group
entry.summary: In this book, I explored differential equations for operation in Lie group and for representations of group Lie in a vector space.
entry.arxiv:comment: English text - 45 pages; Russian text - 47 pages

entry.title: Karl Stein (1913-2000)
entry.summary: Karl Stein was one of the pillars of the German school of several complex variables. In this article his scientific contributions are outlined in historical perspective.

entry.title: Arnold's problem on paper folding
entry.summary: It is a story about the problem whether folding a square on the plane can increase its perimeter. The paper is written primary for school students.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Zadachi Sankt-peterburgskoj matematicheskoj olimpiady shkol'nikov po matematike 2008

entry.title: Odd One Out
entry.summary: This article covers my second talk at the Gathering for Gardner in March, 2010. It is about an Odd One Out puzzle I invented, after having been inspired by Martin Gardner. I do not like Odd One Out questions; that is why I invented one.

entry.title: SIAM 2020
entry.summary: Some observations are made about how the Society for Industrial and Applied Mathematics (SIAM) might be better oriented to serve the industrial and interdisciplinary mathematics community in the future.

entry.title: Gravity, an essential property of matter?
entry.summary: The aim of this short note is to realize that the main reason for non-mechanistic explanation of Newton's gravitational attraction, is explicitly encapsulated in his famous General Scholium of the second Edition of Principia Mathematica (1713).

entry.title: Victor Borisovich Lidskii (1924-2008)
entry.summary: This is the editors' preface to the volume "Operator theory and its applications, in memory of V.B.Lidskii (1924-2008)". The volume is due to be published by the American Mathematical Society in the series American Mathematical Society Translations, series 2, volume 231.

entry.title: Roots of polynomials of degrees 3 and 4
entry.summary: We present the solutions of equations of degrees 3 and 4 using Galois theory and some simple Fourier analysis for finite groups, together with historical comments on these and other solution methods.

entry.title: Exploring Mount Neverest
entry.summary: The problem `Exploring Mount Neverest' by Henry Ernest Dudeney is solved. Dudeney formulated the problem in the beginning of the 20th century and gave a non-optimal solution (without estimating the non-optimality).

entry.title: Boring mathematics, artistes pompiers and impressionists
entry.summary: The 19th century impressionist movement, as a reaction to "art pompier", is proposed as a comparison with modern evolutions in mathematics.
entry.arxiv:comment: with respect to the previous version, only fixed the hyperref

entry.title: The `Real' Schwarz Lemma
entry.summary: The purpose of this note is to discuss the real analogue of the Schwarz lemma from complex analysis.

entry.title: Mathematics and Economics of Leonid Kantorovich
entry.summary: This is a short overview of the contribution of Leonid Kantorovich into the formation of the modern outlook on the interaction between mathematics and economics.

entry.title: Centre for Mathematical Sciences India (CMS): Professor A.M. Mathai's 75th Birthday
entry.summary: A brief overview on the Centre for Mathematical Sciences India, established in 1977, and its teaching and research programme is given.

entry.title: Is Zero a Natural Number?
entry.summary: It is argued that zero should be considered as a cardinal number but not an ordinal number. One should make a clear distinction between order types that are labels for well-ordered sets and ordinal numbers that are labels for the elements in these sets.

entry.title: The Monty Hall Problem: Switching is Forced by the Strategic Thinking
entry.summary: Game versions of the Monty Hall Problem are discussed. The focus is on the principle of eliminating the dominated strategies, both in the zero-sum and noncooperative formulations.

entry.title: Gerhard Hochschild (1915/2010) A Mathematician of the XXth Century
entry.summary: Gerhard Hochschild's contribution to the development of mathematics in the XX century is succinctly surveyed. We start with a personal and mathematical biography, and then consider with certain detail his contributions to algebraic groups and Hopf algebras.

entry.title: The Mathematical Background of Lomonosov's Contribution
entry.summary: This is a short overview of the influence of mathematicians and their ideas on the creative contribution of Mikhailo Lomonosov on the occasion of the tercentenary of his birth.

entry.title: Projektive Geometrie
entry.summary: This is an introduction (in German) to projective geometry by the late Heinz Lueneburg. Projective spaces are treated as lattices with particular properties, and finite geometries receive special attention. The final chapters deal with Segre and Grassmann manifolds.
entry.arxiv:comment: Edited by Theo Grundhoefer and Karl Strambach, with an appendix by Karl Strambach

entry.title: Ken Kunen: Algebraist
entry.summary: This paper is a greatly expanded version of a talk I gave in April 2009 at KunenFest. It describes Ken's work in algebra, particularly using automated deduction tools.
entry.arxiv:comment: 7 pages, to appear in a special issue of Topology and its Applications in honor of Ken Kunen

entry.title: An easily verifiable proof of the Brouwer fixed point theorem
entry.summary: We give a remarkably elementary proof of the Brouwer fixed point theorem. The proof is verifiable for most of the mathematicians.

entry.title: Banach matchboxes problem and a congruence for primes
entry.summary: Using an identity arising in the known Banach probability problem on matchboxes, we prove an unexpected congruence for odd prime $p:$ for $1\leq k\leq \frac{p-1}{2},\enskip \sum_{i=1}^{p-2k-1}2^{i-1}\binom{k-1+i}{k}\equiv 0\pmod p.$

entry.title: Aftermath
entry.summary: I take a quick overview at the recent development of combinatorics and its current directions, as a discipline in its own right, as part of mathematics, and as part of science and wider society.

entry.title: Elementary trigonometry based on a first order differential equation
entry.summary: It is shown that with appropriate boundary conditions, a real function satisfying the differential equation $f'(x) = f(x+a)$ has all known properties of the sine function. A number of elementary derivations are presented including proofs for periodicity and trigonometric identities.

entry.title: Kinds of concepts
entry.summary: The central focus is on clarifying the distinction between sets and proper classes. To this end we identify several categories of concepts (surveyable, definite, indefinite), and we attribute the classical set theoretic paradoxes to a failure to appreciate the distinction between surveyability and definiteness.

entry.title: Truth and the liar paradox
entry.summary: We analyze the informal notion of truth and conclude that it can be formalized in essentially two distinct ways: constructively, in terms of provability, or classically, as a hierarchy of concepts which satisfy Tarski's biconditional in limited settings. This leads to a complete resolution of the liar paradox.

entry.title: Boris Venkov's Theory of Lattices and Spherical Designs
entry.summary: Boris Venkov passed away on November 10 2011 just 5 days before his 77th birthday. This article gives a short survey of the mathematical work of Boris Venkov in this direction.

entry.title: A simple proof on the inequality of arithmetic and geometric means
entry.summary: In this short paper we show that the inequality of arithmetic and geometric means is reduced to another interesting inequality, and a proof is provided.

entry.title: Sylvester's, Wolstenholme's, Morley's and Lehmer's Congruence Theorems Revisited
entry.summary: Elementary proofs of Sylvester's, Wolstenholme's, Morley's and Lehmer's congruence theorems

entry.title: Nova series infinita maxime convergens perimetrum ellipsis exprimens
entry.summary: The title says what is done here. Euler finds a news series for the arc of an ellipse. The paper is translated from the Latin original into German.

entry.title: Nova demonstratio, quod evolutio potestatum binomii Newtoniana etiam pro exponentibus fractis valeat
entry.summary: Here Euler notes the recursive relation for the general binomial coefficients, by assuming that (1+x)^a can be expanded in a power series.

entry.title: Variae considerationes circa series hypergeometricas
entry.summary: Euler gives an asymptotic approximation for the function f(x) and recognizes that he is trying to interpolate the factorial function introduced in E19 "De progressionibus transcendentibus seu quarum termini generales algebraice dari nequeunt". The paper is translated from Euler's Latin original into German.

entry.title: Disquitiones analyticae super evolutione potestatis trinomialis (1+x+xx)^n
entry.summary: Euler investigates the Taylorseries of (1+x+xx)^n and uses the results to evaluates some integrals which are today often proved with the calculus of residues.

entry.title: Methodus succincta summas serierum infinitarum per formulas differentiales investigandi
entry.summary: This paper has more formal series with Bernoulli numbers and the Riemann zeta function. He gives the generating function for the Bernoulli numbers. The paper is translated from the Latin original into German.

entry.title: Demonstratio insignis theorematis numerici circa uncias potestatum binomialium
entry.summary: This paper is about the product z^q/(1 - z)^(q + 1)(1 + (z/(1 - z)))^p, Euler gives the Talylor-Series and takes a closer look at the coefficient.

entry.title: How would Riemann evaluate $Œ∂(2n)$?
entry.summary: Commenting on an observation of Prof. Edwards, this note presents a method of evaluation of $\zeta(2n)$ that follows easily from Riemann's own representation of the zeta function.
entry.arxiv:comment: 3 pages, to appear in The American Mathematical Monthly

entry.title: Revisiting a Number-Theoretic Puzzle: The Census-Taker Problem
entry.summary: The current work revisits the results of L.F. Meyers and R. See in [3], and presents the census-taker problem as a motivation to introduce the beautiful theory of numbers.

entry.title: Applied Mathematics, the Hans van Duijn way
entry.summary: This is a former PhD student's take on his teacher's scientific philosophy. I describe a set of 'principles' that I believe are conducive to good applied mathematics, and that I have learnt myself from observing Hans van Duijn in action.

entry.title: Special Smarandache Curves in E1 3
entry.summary: In this study, we determine some special Smarandache curves in E1 3.We give some characterizations consequences of Smarandache curves.

entry.title: Un portrait kal√©idoscopique du jeune Camille Jordan
entry.summary: This paper aims to provide an overview of recent researches studies on Camille Jordan's early works (1860-1870). We especially shed new light on the relation between Galois and Jordan by discussing the collective dimensions of Jordan's works and their receptions.

entry.title: Why Banach algebras?
entry.summary: We give a brief overview of the area of Banach algebras, intended for a general mathematical audience.
entry.arxiv:comment: 6 pages; a shortened version appeared the the Research Notes department of the CMS Notes; some typos fixed

entry.title: Covering Numbers in Linear Algebra
entry.summary: We compute the minimal cardinality of a covering (resp. an irredundant covering) of a vector space over an arbitrary field by proper linear subspaces. Analogues for affine linear subspaces are also given.

entry.title: The Torii of phases
entry.summary: The import of the magnitude of fourier coefficients of a pitch class set is fairly well known. This paper deals with the angular component of these compelx numbers, the phase. It enables to shed new light on triads, the Tonnetz, and continuous gestures between diverse pc-sets, even those with different cardinalities.

entry.title: A L'hospital's rule for multivariable functions
entry.summary: We prove a version of L'hospital's rule for multivariable functions, which holds for non-isolated singular points. We also give an algorithm for resolving many indeterminate limits with isolated singular points.

entry.title: On the half line: K. Ramachandra
entry.summary: A short biographical note on the life and works of K. Ramachandra, one of the leading mathematicians in the field of analytic number theory in the second half of the twentieth century.

entry.title: Ramanujan's q-continued fractions and Schroeder-like numbers
entry.summary: In a recent paper G. Bhatnagar has given simple proofs of some of Ramanujan's continued fractions. In this note we show that some variants of these continued fractions are generating functions of q-Schroeder-like numbers.

entry.title: Of Bombs and Boats and Mice and Men: A Random tour through some scaling laws
entry.summary: A trip through some of the standard examples of dimensional analysis and scaling, with further thoughts on yacht prices, growing up, mice, bears and marsupials.

entry.title: The Work of John Tate
entry.summary: This is my article on Tate's work for the second volume in the book series on the Abel Prize winners. True to the epigraph, I have attempted to explain it in the context of the "great reformulation".

entry.title: On some applications of complex numbers to polar equations and cycloidal curves
entry.summary: The efficacy of using complex numbers for understanding geometric questions related to polar equations and general cycloids is demonstrated.

entry.title: A theorem with constructive and non-constructive proofs
entry.summary: We present a very simple example of a theorem with constructive and non-constructive proofs: the equation c^2 x^2 - (c^2 + c)x + c = 0 has a solution.

entry.title: Mathematics, Love, and Tattoos
entry.summary: Reflections on the film "Rites of Love and Math" (directed by Reine Graves and the author) and its "formula of love".
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages. Contribution to the Proceedings of the annual Symposium "Matematica e Cultura" in Venice (Italy), where the film was shown (March, 2012). To be published by Springer Verlag

entry.title: Antiderivatives Exist without Integration
entry.summary: We present a proof that any continuous function with domain including a closed interval yields an antiderivative of that function on that interval. This is done without the need of any integration comparable to that of Riemann, Cauchy, or Darboux. The proof is based on one given by Lebesgue in 1905.

entry.title: On Those Analytic Functions of One Variable which possess an Algebraic Addition Theorem
entry.summary: This is a literal word-for-word translation from the German of the article by Paul Koebe which contains a proof of Weierstrass's famous theorem characterizing all analytic functions which possess an algebraic addition theorem.

entry.title: On a theorem concerning the elliptic functions
entry.summary: This is a literal word-for-word translation from the French of Phragmen's proof (the first such published) of Weierstrass' famous theorem characterizing all analytic functions which possess an algebraic addition theorem.

entry.title: Key developments in geometry in the 19th Century
entry.summary: This paper describes several key discoveries in the 19th century that led to the modern theory of manifolds in the twentieth century: intrinsic differential geometry, projective geometry and higher dimensional manifolds and Riemannian geometry.

entry.title: Wronskians and linear independence
entry.summary: We give a new and simple proof of the fact that a finite family of analytic functions has a zero Wronskian only if it is linearly dependent.

entry.title: Mathematics in the Age of the Turing Machine
entry.summary: The article gives a survey of mathematical proofs that rely on computer calculations and formal proofs.
entry.arxiv:comment: 45 pages. This article will appear in "Turing's Legacy," ASL Lecture Notes in Logic, editor Rodney G. Downey

entry.title: Hans Grauert (1930-2011)
entry.summary: Hans Grauert died in September of 2011. This article reviews his life in mathematics and recalls some detail his major accomplishments.
entry.arxiv:comment: Written for publication in 2013 in the Jahresber. Deutsch. Math.-Vereinigung

entry.title: Basic geometric proof of the relation between dimensionality of a regular simplex and its dihedral angle
entry.summary: The formula for the dihedral angle of the simplex of n dimensions, arccos(1/n), is derived using classical geometry.
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author because of its pointlessness

entry.title: Erinnerungen an Heinrich Brauner (1928--1990)
entry.summary: Recollections of the Austrian geometer Heinrich Brauner (in German).
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: H. Havlicek, F. Manhart, and B. Odehnal (eds): Proceedings - 33. S\"uddeutsches Kolloquium \"uber Differentialgeometrie, Institut f\"ur Diskrete Mathematik und Geometrie, TU Wien, Wien, 2008, pp. 14-34

entry.title: A short proof of d'Alemberts theorem
entry.summary: A classical theorem of d'Alembert states that if a polynomial P(x) with real coefficients has a non-real root x=a+ib, then it also has a root x=a-ib. We give a short and elementary inductive proof that avoids any properties of the complex conjugation operator.

entry.title: The Structure of Z-related sets
entry.summary: The paper presents some new results on Z-related sets obtained by computational methods. We give a complete enumeration of all Z-related sets in $\mathbb{Z}_{N}$ for small $N$. Furthermore, we establish that there is a reasonable permutation group action representing the Z-relation.

entry.title: Enumeration of Vuza Canons
entry.summary: A Vuza canon is a non periodic factorization of the finite cyclic $ \mathbb{Z}_{N}$. The aim of this paper is to present some new results for generating Vuza canons, and to give new minoration of their number for some values of N.

entry.title: New relations for the old triangle
entry.summary: In this note we show that in addition to two integers forming a Pythagorean triple, there also exist two irrational numbers in terms of which this Pythagorean triple can also be obtained. We also put forward a relation between these two pairs and the hypotenuse of a Pythagorean triangle.

entry.title: Outer median triangles
entry.summary: We define the notions of outer medians and outer median triangles. We show that outer median triangles enjoy similar properties to that of the median triangle.

entry.title: Geometry of moduli spaces of meromorphic connections on curves, Stokes data, wild nonabelian Hodge theory, hyperkahler manifolds, isomonodromic deformations, Painleve equations, and relations to Lie theory
entry.summary: Summary of main work 1999-2012

entry.title: On the characterization of Galois extensions
entry.summary: We present a shortcut to the familiar characterizations of finite Galois extensions, based on an idea from an earlier Monthly note by Sonn and Zassenhaus.
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages; to appear in Amer. Math. Monthly (2014)

entry.title: Note on Malmst√®n's paper De Integralibus quibusdam definitis seriebusque infinitis
entry.summary: We present a proof of the functional equation of the Riemann zeta-function or more precisely the Dirichlet eta-function, which proof seems to be new but follows almost immediately from Malmst\`en's paper ``De integralibus quibusdam definitis seriebusque infinitis``

entry.title: Continuous q-Hermite polynomials: An elementary approach
entry.summary: This overview article gives an elementary approach to continuous q-Hermite polynomials. We stress their relation to Fibonacci, Lucas and Chebyshev polynomials and to some q-analogues of these polynomials.

entry.title: The n-th smallest term for any finite sequence of real numbers
entry.summary: In this paper we find the formula that gives the n-th smallest term in a given finite sequence of real numbers.

entry.title: Leonardo and the Pseudo-RCO
entry.summary: There are two hypotheses on Leonardo's polyhedron based on the Pseudo-RCO and drawn for Luca Pacioli's book: Leonardo made an error, or: Leonardo draw it with intention, as it is. We give arguments, which support the Intention-hypothesis.

entry.title: Methodus inveniendi lineas curvas maximi minimive proprietate gaudentes, sive solutio problematis isoperimetrici lattissimo sensu accepti
entry.summary: This translation has been withdrawn due to certain imperfections and mistakes, which are corrected in the version uploaded at The Euler Archive (see E65 at http://www.eulerarchive.org/)
entry.arxiv:comment: This paper has been withdrawn by the author

entry.title: Notes and Remarks on certain logarithmic integrals
entry.summary: Logarithmic integrals revisited. We consider integrals of the form $\int_0^1 \ln{\ln{(\frac{1}{x})}}R{(x)}{\rm d}x$ again, where $R{(x)}$ is a rational function, and we will explain a way to obtain their values.

entry.title: Sheaf Representations for Algebraic Systems. A personal historical account
entry.summary: From personal experience, I report about the development of sheaf representations for algebraic structures between the years 1966 and 1976. Starting with rings, lattice-ordered groups and rings it turns to general algebraic structures.

entry.title: Otto Toeplitz: Algebraiker der unendlichen Matrizen
entry.summary: This article is about life and work of Otto Toeplitz, who was influenced by the ideas of Felix Klein and David Hilbert.
entry.arxiv:comment: published version, Mathematische Semesterberichte, in German

entry.title: On certain definite integrals and infinite series
entry.summary: A translation of Kummer`s paper On certain definite integrals and infinite series
entry.arxiv:comment: 18 pages, Kummer's original is written in Latin, the two other papers, Kummer is referring to, are contained in the references

entry.title: Was ist Unendlichkeit - und wenn ja, wie viele?
entry.summary: This article, written in German language, gives a very elementary introduction to infinite sets. It is meant for interested non-mathematicians.
entry.arxiv:comment: 21 pages. In German. To appear in Cantor-Heft 15 (2013)

entry.title: On Leonardo da Vinci's proof of the Theorem of Pythagoras
entry.summary: We show that Leonardo da Vinci's well known proof of the Pythagorean theorem is due to Mayer and not to da Vinci.
entry.arxiv:comment: update with a few historical corrections

entry.title: De Divino Errore
entry.summary: 'De Divina Proportione' was one of the most widely read mathematical books. Yet there is an unmistakable erroneous theorem, which was questioned by Dutchman Jos Janssens and confirmed by his compatriot Rinus Roelofs. Did anyone ever notice this error?

entry.title: Jensen-type inequality for non-convex functions
entry.summary: In this note we prove Jensen-type inequality for certain non-convex functions. We apply our idea to prove some inequalities which were suggested at some high-level math olympiades.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages with 6 figures; In Russian language

entry.title: On the roots of $a^x+a^{-x}=x$
entry.summary: We provide an analytical closed-form solution of the exponential equation $a^x+a^{-x}=x$ for a specific value $a$, discuss the number of roots in general case, and provide bounds on the roots.

entry.title: Experimental library of univalent formalization of mathematics
entry.summary: This paper contains a discussion of a library of formalized mathematics for the proof assistant Coq which the author worked on in 2011-13.

entry.title: Some Thoughts on the Teaching of Mathematics -- ten years later
entry.summary: I describe some deep-seated problems in higher mathematical education, and give some ideas for their solution -- I advocate a move away from the traditional introduction of mathematics through calculus, and towards computation and discrete mathematics.
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages, to appear in Notices of the AMS

entry.title: Forgotten Motives: the Varieties of Scientific Experience
entry.summary: Personal recollections about Alexandre Grothendieck and early days of his theory of motives
entry.arxiv:comment: 10 pages. Small corrections inserted. Published in: "Alexandre Grothendieck: A Mathematical Portrait." Ed. by Leila Schneps, International Press of Boston, 2014, 307 pp

entry.title: Donald Arthur Preece: A life in statistics, mathematics and music
entry.summary: Biography and publications list for Donald Arthur Preece, who died on 6 January 2014, who made many contributions in statistics (experimental design) and in combinatorics.

entry.title: Translation of Reidemeister's "Einf√ºhrung in die kombinatorische Topologie"
entry.summary: This is an English translation of Reidemeister's book "Einf\"uhrung in die kombinatorische Topologie" from 1932, the first monograph on combinatorial group theory and topology, with some added comments by the translator and Warren Dicks.

entry.title: Continuity of multivariate rational functions
entry.summary: If the denominator of a rational function of several variables is sum of even powers and the numerator is a monomial, then we give a numerical criterion, using the exponents involved in the expression of the rational function, to decide if the limit at the origin exists or not.

entry.title: Gabriel's Paper Horn
entry.summary: Gabriel's horn is the famous mathematical object that has finite volume and infinite surface area. This article gives a template for making Gabriel's horn out of paper cones. It also describes the mathematics behind the construction of the template.

entry.title: Hat Puzzles
entry.summary: This paper serves as the announcement of my program---a joke version of the Langlands Program. In connection with this program, I discuss an old hat puzzle, introduce a new hat puzzle, and offer a puzzle for the reader.

entry.title: Equa√ß√µes diferenciais pantogr√°ficas: retardo proporcional
entry.summary: We present initially the motivation, definition and basic properties of differential equations with proportional delay. In the last Section we present open problems.

entry.title: Geometry of some taxicab curves
entry.summary: In this paper we present geometry of some curves in Taxicab metric. All curves of second order and trifocal ellipse in this metric are presented. Area and perimeter of some curves are also defined.

entry.title: Eigenvalues of real symmetric matrices
entry.summary: We present a proof of the existence of real eigenvalues of real symmetric matrices which does not rely on any limit or compactness arguments, but only uses the notions of "sup", "inf".
entry.arxiv:comment: 2 pages; appears in the Amer. Math. Monthly (2015)

entry.title: In Limbo: Three Triangle Centers
entry.summary: Yet more candidates are proposed for inclusion in the Encyclopedia of Triangle Centers. Our focus is entirely on simple calculations.

entry.title: Littlewood's proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra: a simpler version
entry.summary: We present an elementary proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, following Cauchy's version but avoiding his use of circular functions. It is written in the same spirit as Littlewood's proof of 1941, but reduces it to more elementary and constructive arguments.

entry.title: A New Proof of Stirling's Formula
entry.summary: A new simple proof of Stirling's formula via the partial fraction expansion for the tangent function is presented.

entry.title: Empirische Theorien im Kontext der Mathematikdidaktik
entry.summary: At two examples dealt with in methodologically different ways it will be pointed out how the concept of an empirical theory (in the sense of the Structuralists) can be useful to specify contents relevant to maths didactics.

entry.title: On Constructive Axiomatic Method
entry.summary: In this last version of the paper one may find a critical overview of some recent philosophical literature on Axiomatic Method and Genetic Method.

entry.title: An American mathematician in Moscow, or how I destroyed the Soviet Union
entry.summary: Reminiscences about I. M. Gel'fand on the 100th anniversary of his birth, and about mathematical life in Moscow in the former Soviet Union.
entry.arxiv:journal_ref: Notices of the American Mathematical Society 61 (2014), 186--189

entry.title: History of Catalan numbers
entry.summary: We give a brief history of Catalan numbers, from their first discovery in the 18th century to modern times. This note will appear as an appendix in Richard Stanley's forthcoming book on Catalan numbers.

entry.title: How does a topologist classify the letters of the alphabet?
entry.summary: The paper approaches to the reader to topology with a curious example of topological classification by homeomorphisms applied to the letters of the alphabet viewed as subsets of Euclidean plane.

entry.title: "Marvelous cancellations": T.J. Stieltjes' letters concerning the zeta function
entry.summary: This article introduces and translates letters from T.J. stieltjes (1856-1894) to C. Hermite (1822-1891) regarding Stieltjes' published notes claiming to have solved B. Riemann's conjecture "it is very probable that all the roots [of the zeta function] are real."

entry.title: Constructing the fixed point of a non-isometric plane similarity
entry.summary: We present an algorithm for constructing the fixed point of a general non-isometric similarity of the plane.

entry.title: Dimensional Analysis: A Centenary Update
entry.summary: It is time to renew old ways of thinking about dimensional analysis. Specifically, more than $n-r$ invariants and more than one functional relation between invariants need to be considered simultaneously. Thus generalized, dimensional analysis can yield more information than previously recognized.

entry.title: Symbolic Languages and Ars Combinatoria
entry.summary: This article analyses some paragraphs of the Dissertatio de Arte Combinatoria (1666) where G.W. Leibniz considers the syntax of a language with a given number of primitive terms. We propose a new formulation which generalizes the philosopher conception of such a formal system.

entry.title: Resolution of the Surprise Exam Paradox
entry.summary: We present a resolution of the celebrated "Surprise Exam Paradox". We argue that if the surprise exam story is analyzed using the exact same meaning of the notion of "surprise" as is dictated by the story itself, then no paradox arises.

entry.title: Dissecting Equilateral Triangles into Non-Congruent Equilateral Triangles: A Novel Proof of Tutte's Result
entry.summary: In this paper, we show that an equilateral triangle cannot be dissected into finitely many smaller equilateral triangles, no two of which share two vertices. We do this without the use of Electrical Networks.

entry.title: Finite groups with a certain number of cyclic subgroups
entry.summary: In this short note, we describe the finite groups $G$ having $|G|-1$ cyclic subgroups. This leads to a nice characterization of the symmetric group $S_3$.
entry.arxiv:comment: accepted for publication in Amer. Math. Monthly

entry.title: On the History of Number Line
entry.summary: The notion of number line was formed in XX c. We consider the generation of this conception in works by M. Stiefel (1544), Galilei (1633), Euler (1748), Lambert (1766), Bolzano (1830-1834), Meray (1869-1872), Cantor (1872), Dedekind (1872), Heine (1872) and Weierstrass (1861-1885).

entry.title: Rolle Theorem and Bolzano-Cauchy Theorem from the end of the 17th century to K. Weierstrass epoch
entry.summary: A history of two Rolle Theorems, about the root of derivative and about root interval from 1690 till the end of XIX century.

entry.title: Marching in squares
entry.summary: In this articles we consider very mathematical (if not very plausible) geometric marching. Our marchers will exhibit beautiful mathematics, some familiar and some less so. In a final summary section we discuss the point of all the fancy footwork.

entry.title: What to do to have your paper rejected!
entry.summary: We aim to highlight certain points and considerations for graduate students and young researchers, which should be avoided in submissions to good research journals. Observing these remarks could substantially decrease the probability of rejections of papers.

entry.title: Sur le th√©or√®me des trois distances et la construction des gammes
entry.summary: We explain the link between the so-called "three gap theorem" and the construction of musical scales. Nous expliquons le lien entre un th\'eor\`eme classique d'approximation diophantienne (le th\'eor\`eme des trois distances), et la construction des gammes en musique.

entry.title: Edward Nelson (1932-2014)
entry.summary: In the article we give an appreciation of Edward Nelson's multifaceted contribution to mathematics, and particularly to foundational theories of infinitesimals.
entry.arxiv:comment: 4 pages. Appears in The Review of Symbolic Logic, 2015

entry.title: 10 Questions about Boggle Logic Puzzles
entry.summary: Boggle logic puzzles are based on the popular word game Boggle, where you are given list of words, and your goal is to recreate a Boggle board. In this paper we give an overview of known results and then propose a number of problems related to these puzzles.

entry.title: Bourlet's Theorem for the product of differential operators, an application of the operator method and a proof for $\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n^2}=\frac{œÄ^2}{6}$, that Euler missed, derived from difference equations
entry.summary: We give another proof for \[ \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{1}{n^2}=\frac{\pi^2}{6} \] that basically follows from the theory of difference equations.

entry.title: Explicit formulas for orthogonal polynomials derived from their difference equation
entry.summary: We solve the difference equation with linear coefficients by the Momentenansatz to obtain explicit formulas for orthogonal polynomials.
entry.arxiv:comment: 16 pages, everything is derived from older sources from the 18th and 19th century

entry.title: Geometry in the Age of Enlightenment
entry.summary: This paper describes the evolution of aspects of differential and algebraic gometry from the mid 17th century till the end of the 18th century.

entry.title: Mystery of the 18th Elephant Solved
entry.summary: This paper attempts to explain the mystery behind an 18th elephant that appears in many popular legends involving the division of a herd of 17 elephants into groups in the ratio 1/2:1/3:1/9.

entry.title: Can we admit the way in which $\sin(x)$ is typically defined?
entry.summary: I review some facts which the usual sen(x) and cos(x) definitions are based on. The purpose of this paper is to show that this facts can be proved if we assume some basic ideas of elementary geometry.

entry.title: Unraveling the secret of Benjamin Franklin: Constructing Franklin squares of higher order
entry.summary: Benjamin Franklin constructed three squares which have amazing properties, and his method of construction has been a mystery to date. In this article, we divulge his secret and show how to construct such squares for any order.

entry.title: The oldest example of compound interest in Sumer: Seventh power of four-thirds
entry.summary: In the present paper I shall clarify that the origin of compound interest goes back 4400 years to Sumer by showing the Sumerian scribe of Enmetena Foundation Cone calculated seventh power of four-thirds.

entry.title: The amazing story of a forgotten golden flag
entry.summary: We describe the most probable geometric design of the Chilean Independence Flag, which uses the golden ratio in many of its components. We also discuss some related historical aspects.

entry.title: Union of n Disks: Remote Centers, Common Origin
entry.summary: Explicit area expressions are known for a special case, due to Tao & Wu (1987), and lead to calculation of integrals in applied probability.

entry.title: From the theory of "congeneric surd equations" to "Segre's bicomplex numbers"
entry.summary: We will study the historical pathway of the emergence of Tessarines or Bicomplex numbers, from their origin as "imaginary" solutions of irrational equations, to their insertion in the context of study of the algebras of hypercomplex numbers.

entry.title: A Proof of Irrationality of $œÄ$ by Contraposition
entry.summary: We point out that the proof of irrationality of $\pi$ by Niven can be modified to a proof by contraposition. As a warm-up, we also give a proof of irrationality of $\sqrt{2}$ and $\sqrt{3}$ in a similar way.

entry.title: What is Aperiodic Order?
entry.summary: This article provides a brief introductory account of the theory of aperiodic order.

entry.title: Game Theory (Open Access textbook with 165 solved exercises)
entry.summary: This is an Open Access textbook on non-cooperative Game Theory with 165 solved exercises.

entry.title: Capturing, Ordering and Gaussianity in 2D
entry.summary: We collect various facts related loosely to random Gaussian quadrilaterals in the plane. For example, a side of a degenerate quadrilateral (one point inside three others) has a density that is non-Rayleigh.

entry.title: Mocposite functions
entry.summary: Traditional mathematical notation can lead to confusion. Expressions that appear to define composite functions sometimes do not. A particular example with engineering applications is studied in detail.
entry.arxiv:comment: To appear in the American Mathematical Monthly

entry.title: Graphs of real functions with pathological behaviors
entry.summary: This paper deals with constructions and properties of unusual function from R to R, as discontinuous additive functions and everywhere surjections.

entry.title: Cyclic extensions are radical
entry.summary: We show that finite Galois extensions with cyclic Galois group are radical.
entry.arxiv:comment: 1 page. This has been published as filler in the American Mathematical Monthly

entry.title: From $e$ to $œÄ$: Derivation of the Wallis formula for $œÄ$ from $e$
entry.summary: In this Note, we start off with the primary representation of e and from there present an elementary short proof for the Wallis formula for $\pi$.

entry.title: The Triangle of Smallest Area Which Circumscribes a Semicircle
entry.summary: An interesting problem that determine a triangle of smallest area which circumscribes a semicircle is solved. Then a generalized golden right triangles sequence $T_n$ is obtained, and an interesting construction of the maximum generalized golden right triangle $T_2$ is also shown.

entry.title: 3D Printing & the Artists Known As the Fauves
entry.summary: In this short, chatty paper, I describe how my attempt to use mathematics to create a 3D print of a school portrait led me a group of early 20th century French artists known as the Fauves.

entry.title: Euler and Chebyshev: From the sphere to the plane and backwards
entry.summary: We report on the works of Euler and Chebyshev on the drawing of geographical maps. We point out relations with questions about the fitting of garments that were studied by Chebyshev.

entry.title: The oldest example of $œÄ=3+1/8$ in Sumer: Calculation of the area of a circular plot
entry.summary: In this paper I shall show that the formula 0:4,48 times circumference squared for the area of a circle, which occurs in a few Babylonian mathematical texts, can be traced back to at the latest the twenty-third century BCE.

entry.title: On the weighted Gau√ü--Radau Quadrature
entry.summary: In this short note, we collect some facts on the weighted Gau{\ss}--Radau quadrature. In particular, we focus on the location of the Gau\ss--Radau points being a continuous function of the $L^1$-weighting function.

entry.title: Georges de Rham 1903--1990
entry.summary: This is an English translation of the obituary notice by Beno Eckmann, appearing in Elemente der Mathematik 47.3 (1992) 118--122 (in German).
entry.arxiv:comment: Distributed with permission of publisher. Original available at <http://eudml.org/doc/141534>

entry.title: A Mathematic Expression of the Genes of Chinese Traditional Philosophy
entry.summary: We provide a mathematic model for the Traditional Yin-and-Yang Double Fish Diagram which from Chinese Traditional Philosophy.

entry.title: Richard Dedekind: Style and Influence
entry.summary: This text is based on an invited talk at the Dedekind Symposium at Braunschweig in October 2016. It summarizes views from my recent commented edition of Dedekinds two books on the foundations of mathematics.

entry.title: General Two-variable Functions on the Slide-rule
entry.summary: We discuss the general theory of realizing two-variable fuctions on slide rules (based on our paper 1977) and offer some new scales for practical use.

entry.title: Few more Comments on Benford's Law
entry.summary: It is pointed out that the language of quotient groups and wrapped distributions allows an elementary discussion of Benford's Law, and adds arguments supporting wide-spread observability of this statistics.

entry.title: On the history of the Ulam's Conjugacy
entry.summary: We show the results on the history of the invention of the conjugacy $h(x)=\frac{2}{\pi}\arcsin\sqrt{x}$ of one-dimensional $[0,\, 1]\rightarrow [0,\, 1]$ maps $f(x)=4x(1-x)$ and $g(x)=1-|1-2x|$.

entry.title: Conformally correct tilings
